captions.text:
Olympus Mons, the tallest mountain in our
Solar System, towers 21,000 meters above the

surface of Mars -- nearly two and a half times
the height of Mount Everest. On Earth, you

would need a spacesuit to survive at that
altitude - but could there even be a mountain
that tall here on our home planet?

Based on the strength of Earth's gravity and
the density and strength of rock, in principle

you could make a single conical mountain that
stretched between New York and Chicago and

soared over 45km! That's twice the size of
Olympus Mons and definitely dwarfs Everest.

However, there are a couple of reasons why
we can't actually have that humongous of a
mountain on Earth:

For one, Earth's crust is made up of continental
plates that essentially float in the semi-solid

rock of the mantle below. If you add more
weight above the surface, they sink lower

into the earth's hot interior, and when they
sink far enough, they soften and basically

melt. For our conical mountain, that gives
a new height limit of just 15km.

As well, the powerful collision of two tectonic
plates, which creates mountains in the first

place, also fractures and cracks the rock,
weakening its structure and exposing it to
erosion.

Over millions of years, freeze-thaw cycles
pry at these cracks, while winds claw at the

slopes and streams and glaciers carve deep
valleys into the mountainside, all weakening
the mountain's support. This can end badly.

For example, 3,764m tall Aoraki/Mount Cook
in New Zealand had its top fall off one night
in 1991, trimming it down to a 3,754m mountain.

Given all the factors that conspire to limit
the height of mountains - sinking into the

earth's mantle, fractures, and erosion - I
wouldn't bet on our tallest mountains getting

too much taller than they already are. Then
again, Mount Everest is still growing, 50

years from now, it could be 30 cm taller than
it is today... or it could be a good deal

shorter. We'll just have to wait around to
find out. And, who knows? Maybe we'll be on
Mars by then, anyway.

about Science and Art the less you care about these far-off pipedreams but 
there's a kid in me who just thinks it would be rad, now I know about

comments.text:
+joeman543 We've solved solar radiation, but somewhat recent missions have 
shown that there's radiation from other celestial bodies that can/will 
interfere with long term passengers that have no current solutions.

Radiation isn't the main problem anyway, it's energy. How do we store and 
use energy efficiently enough to get us to the other end of the trip 
safely? Our current methods of propulsion are unbelievably, mind-bogglingly 
inefficient, so they just won't do

comments.text:
Colonization? Not really sold on that for the "near future".

However, between Mars One and NASA's future attempts I believe in our 
lifetime we may just see some various form of landing provided we keep 
funding projects like these. Mars One very well may end up in a one way 
version whereby passengers may make it to the surface but not be resupplied 
thus being stranded, etc. As it is there are preparations for remote mining 
missions to be done via rover whereby samples are sent back to earth. I 
believe once that and an orbit has been completed further pushes might be 
made. Many space agencies don't have the budgets they used to and have been 
relegated into the background now that defense contracts/ cold war races 
aren't the utmost priority in discovering missile tech so these things will 
take time. NASA spends a great deal of time just trying to select missions 
or partner companies and make them the most beneficial/ cost effective 
endeavors in their budget.
comments.author: Zack Young

comments.text:
There will be two stories for the foreseeable future. Running concurrent, 
and both true. The first is lead by NASA and the ESA which supply the 
public domain narratives. This is almost negligible. This isn't where the 
breakthroughs and discoveries ever happen. The core story is much deeper 
and kept from the public. Humanity has already colonized the moons of 
Jupiter, and even beyond to Saturn Neptune and Uranus. We are working on 
conjunction with a galactic council that both advances us technologically, 
and preserves us as a species from the threat of malevolent interstellar 
societies. Now, you have a very large problem to deal with. Yes you 
personally. Because you have just been given a truthful answer to your 
question, but you may never find the substantiation to the answer you were 
provided that you feel you are entitled to. You should believe the surface 
narratives, because they are true as well, but they are child's play in 
comparison the nature of life in the universe, and even in this solar 
system.
comments.author: Josh Morgan

comments.text:
The Olympus Mons has an incredibly gentle slope. The height is 22 km above 
the local relief, but the diameter of the mountain is 624 km. It covers 
roughly the same area as Italy *(!)*, so it is better described as a huge 
region sticking out above the Martian crust than as a mountain. You'd need 
a bubble level to even know you actually were on a slope.

So it'd be less climbing on it than it would just be landing in the area in 
the first place, or rolling slowly to it's center in a wheeled vehicle.

comments.text:
Thanks for this random video showing up! Say, I have a question for you 
guys.

Have you ever heard of or seen a video from like 5-8 yhears ago about what 
will happen to the earth after we're gone? I'm not talking about the Life 
After Humans series (or w/e it's called, though that's a good one.) What I 
remember and want to re-watch is a series that goes hundreds of thousands 
and even millions of years into a hypothetical future, showing what the 
continents might look like and even what our animals and plants would 
evolve into. Himalayas would become an extremely high-altitude area, and 
cephalopods would become the next creatures to start evolving higher brain 
functions.

I wish I could remember what that special was! If you have an inkling on 
this, great! If not, oh well! Data for those predictions have inevitably 
changed since then hahaha!﻿

comments.text:
+Tony joe
1) Its "mt chimborazo" unless you are trying to yank me.

2) The Island of Hawaii is recognized as a volcanic mountain on its own. 
You cannot count a volcano that is part of a  continent. A Mountain is a 
freestanding geological structure

This is why you can look at Mauna Kea as a mountain or, more precisely, one 
of Hawaii's peaks, unto itself or you can look at Hawaii as the WHOLE 
mountain. Meanwhile you cannot take Mt. Chimborazo as anything but the 
mountain but itself.

Everest.

comments.author: Oculus Universale

comments.text:
Also the movement of plates limits the height of volcanos on earth. A weak 
point at the bottom of the crust releases magma to the surface, this 
remains stationary, the plates move above that. When volcanoes are in a 
line like the Cascades this is because the plate moved over the stationary 
point creating many volcanoes along the way. 

Mars does not have moving plates, and that is why Olympus Mons got so high 
it just stayed above the same weak point. ﻿

comments.text:
There is already a mountain on Earth that is taller than Everest, sort of. 
The summit of the mountain of Mauna Kea in Hawaii is 4207m above sea level, 
half the height of Everest which stands a 8848m above sea level. However, 
much of Mauna Kea is below sea level and, when measured from it's oceanic 
base to its summit, Mauna Kea scomes in a 10.1km in total base to peak 
height﻿
comments.author: TheWolfHowling

comments.text:

than the top.

comments.author: Thomas Alexander

comments.text:
+Thomas Alexander
Actually the sea level around Mt. Everest would be lower than around 
Hawaii. It's true that the mountain creates additional gravity, but there 
are some funky things going on in in the mantle in the region around India 
that actually give the region a lower gravitational anomaly than what is 
found around hawaii. Take a look at these maps of the Earth's gravitational 
field (geoid) - http://principles.ou.edu/earth_figure_gravity/geoid/

comments.author: Oscillator

comments.text:
+TheWolfHowling What is the highest mountain?

Mount Everest is the highest mountain measured from sea level, and also has 
the highest altitude. 

Mauna Kea is the biggest mountain measured from the ocean floor.

The summit of Mt. Chimborazo is the furthest point from earths core. ( 
Closer to the equator than Mt. Everest)

So I ask again, what is the highest mountain?
comments.author: Dizzy 13

comments.text:
I think that it would be fair to say that Mount Everest is the highest 
mountain
comments.author: TheWolfHowling

comments.text:
That's so true. I hate it when people say that Mount Everest is the tallest 
mountain. It isn't even the farthest from the earth's core. Because the 
Earth's equator bulges, several mountains near the equator are farther from 
the core. There's some mountain in Ecuador that is the farthest from the 
core.

comments.text:
+underdog808 - The Himalayan mountains, of which Everest is the highest, 
started growing when the large landmass of India started moving north from 
its previous position and hit. the even larger landmass of Asia. This 
caused the land (actually, the sea bed) in front of it to crumple and fold 
up, forming the mountains we know and love today. Not just Everest, but the 
whole of the Himalayas are still growing, because India is still shoving 
up...if you look at a map of the area, you can see the effect.﻿
comments.author: Ruth Mckay

comments.text: Why is Mt. Everest still growing?﻿
comments.author: underdog808

comments.text:
Or shrinking, depending on if the tectonic plates are moving away from one 
another.  Sometimes, this causes landmasses to stretch.  An example of this 
is Death Valley: it is currently growing 1/5 of an inch a year because of 
plate tectonics pulling apart.
comments.author: Jack Tilis

comments.text: Tectonic plates are always moving so all mountains are growing

comments.author: lightsidemaster

comments.text:
But Mars does not have continental plates so much, but a rather solid and 
stationary crust, therefore it can support more weight and have higher 
mountains, plus, because of that, it had everlasting hotspots in it's 
geothermal period, making volcanoes way bigger than they could ever get on 
earth (Olympus Mons is a dead volcano). And let's not forget that, while 
Olympus Mons is indeed high, it's also extremely wide, so wide, that if you 
were to stand on it's summit, you wouldn't even notice you were standing on 
a mountain, so much for your skiing holiday.﻿
comments.author: martijn van weele

comments.text:
+skull7492 If Mars had had continental plates before it's mantle solidified 
(which means there is no convection flow, making any continental plates 
irellevant as there is nothing to cause continental drift), we would've 
probably seen traces of that in the form of pushed mountain ranges, 
trenches and volcanic fissures. Also, in the debate about how continental 
plates came to be, it was found that the thicker the crust of a planet 
relative to it's size, the harder it is to crack. I remember reading that 
it was calculated that Earth's crust was already a little too thick to 
crack, and the only reason it did was the weight of our oceans. If Earth 
already defied the odds, then what might have happened on Mars if it had 
had continental plates?
comments.author: martijn van weele

comments.text:
But we don't know for sure if mars does or does not have continental plates 
yet

comments.text:
Even if we manage to Terraform Mars, no one is ever going to be able to 
climb Olympus mons without the aid of a space suit. Mars has 6/10 of 
Earth's gravity. This means that any atmosphere we manage to get around 
Mars will also only be 6/10 as thick. So, the dead zone that covers the top 
1/3 of Mt. Everest will be considerably lower in elevation on Olympus Mons. 
In addition, Olympus Mons is a whole heck of a lot taller than Everest. It 
would be just about impossible for a mountain climber to climb the thing.﻿

+Joel Mörtsell  That is EXACTLY why it would be impossible to climb Olympus 
Mons unaided. The issue is NOT the difficulty of the climb itself, it is 
the dead zone where the atmosphere will no longer support human life. As 
other people here have commented, Olympus Mons actually fully sticks out of 
Mars' atmosphere, meaning there is zero air at the summit, making it 100% 
impossible to climb it without a fully functional space suit.

comments.text:
Olympus Mons was a volcano, so essentially to get that big it must have 
been erupting the very magma it would have sunk into. In any case, Mars's 
core cooled down so the mountain never grows. Mars was too small to sustain 
a hot core. That also resulted in the loss of its magnetic field, which 
resulted in the atmosphere not being shielded from solar wind, hence why 
there is so little of it left.
